title: Fifa transfer window’s paperwork own-goal
text:
Alphabet makes time Google’s key resource 
The first rumour was that files emailed by United could not be opened. Cue social media witticisms about Windows 95, sluggish downloads and the old Microsoft paper-clip (“It looks like you’re trying to make a last-minute transfer deal. Need some help?”). 
The fact so many jumped to that conclusion tells you something about the lasting reputational taint of early word-processing software and the continuing nightmare of document incompatibility in a world of iPhones and tablets. 
It seems more likely that everything was left too late. The scenario will be familiar to anyone who has had to fill in a superficially simple online form under pressure. Fifa introduced online registration to replace a fax-based system prone to overload and corruption. Yet the promise of technology is often confounded by human error: I picture smug Spanish soccer impresarios furiously stabbing at the keyboard, mistyping their Fifa passwords again and again, and hurling Castilian curses at the screen as vital seconds tick by. 
In ordinary offices, the consequences of such snafus are limited. But the outcome of this bureaucratic mess will be worth its own management study. Each club now has to motivate a player who was on course to change teams until just after midnight on Monday, when the computer said No. Related Topics Copyright The Financial Times Limited 2015.
